plants.name: Dianthus caryophyllus
plants.description: Carnations are popular garden flowers known for their fragrant, ruffled blooms. They naturally bloom in cooler fall temperatures, often into October in temperate regions. Carnations have a long history of cultivation and come in a variety of colors, celebrated for their symbolic meanings.
plants.funFact: The carnation is said to have appeared on Earth from the tears of the Virgin Mary in Christian legend, symbolizing love and fascination.

plants.name: Chrysanthemum morifolium
plants.description: Chrysanthemums are quintessential fall-blooming plants. They produce dense, showy flowers in a wide range of colors and shapes. Often blooming strongly in October, chrysanthemums brighten gardens as temperatures drop, heralding the autumn season especially in East Asia and temperate gardens globally.
plants.funFact: In Japan, the chrysanthemum is a symbol of the Emperor and the Imperial family and is celebrated annually during the 'Festival of Happiness'.

plants.name: Fuchsia magellanica
plants.description: This fuchsia species is notable for its bell-shaped flowers with contrasting sepals and petals. Hardy to cooler climates, it blooms into early fall and sometimes beyond, especially in mild maritime climates of the Southern Hemisphere and temperate zones.
plants.bloomingSeason: Summer to Early Autumn (October in Southern Hemisphere)
plants.location: Southern South America and cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Fuchsias are named after the German botanist Leonhart Fuchs and are popular with hummingbirds as their shape facilitates nectar feeding.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: Though more commonly blooming in late spring to early summer in northern regions, in milder or higher altitude areas lupines can bloom later into fall, including October. These tall spikes of vibrant flowers are important for soil nitrogen fixation and support pollinators.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late Spring to Early Fall (some bloom into October)
plants.location: Western North America, parts of Europe and cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Lupines enrich soil fertility by fixing nitrogen from the air, making them valuable in crop rotations and gardening.
